function.term: Term commonly found on child welfare records

biogHist.abstract: Guardian [Child Migrant] was a term used in law for the personal responsible for the well-being of a child who came to Australia as an unaccompanied child migrant after World War II. The child's guardian was the Commonwealth Minister for Immigration, who delegated the role to the State welfare authorities.
biogHist.p: In terms of post-World War II child and youth migration, the guardian of a child was 'a person with the right to make decision about the long-term needs of the child'. A guardian would not always have 'the day to day care of the child'. Under the Commonwealth Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946 the guardian of a child migrant (a non-citizen child) was the Minister for Immigration, who delegated the powers and functions of of guardianship to State welfare authorities. It was generally understood in Australian law that the guardian had a duty to see that the child was provided with food, housing, health and education. However, the guardian had no 'absolute duty' to 'provide the funds for those purposes'.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946, Commonwealth of Australia (1946 - 1973)

descriptiveNote.p: The Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946 defined the role of the 'Guardian' of children who were sent to Australia as unaccompanied child migrants after World War Two.
The 'guardian' of a post-World War Two Child Migrant was the State welfare authority and the 'custodial parent' was usually the Manager or Foster Parent of the Home where the child lived.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Child and Youth Migration to Western Australia (1913 - 1968)
